rmcPollutants.title: Major Air
rmcPollutants.description: Emissions from RMC plants, including the burning of fossil fuels, material transportation, and heavy gear operation, release pollutants that can harm human health with respiratory difficulties, cardiovascular disease, cancer risks, and cause environmental damage like acid rain and smog. Monitoring and controlling these emissions is vital to minimize their impact on both the environment and human well-being.

pm.title: PM
pm.description: Fossil fuels, material transport, and heavy machinery contribute to PM emissions.

noise.title: Noise
noise.description: Machinery on the sites creates noise that can cause ear injury and disturbance.

co.title: CO
co.description: Heavy machinery operation and transportation of equipment contribute to emissions.

vocs.title: VOCs
vocs.description: Released from the storage and handling of solvents, fuels, and certain chemical additives

sox.title: SOx
sox.description: Sulfur-containing fuels and raw materials contribute to emissions.

nox.title: NOx
nox.description: Oxides of Nitrogen are released from the burning of fuel and natural gas.

sox.title: SOx
sox.description: Exposure to SOx can cause irritation in the eyes and respiratory tract, and aggravate conditions like asthma, bronchitis, etc.

noise.title: Noise
noise.description: Excessive noise can lead to hearing loss, sleep disturbances, high blood pressure, headaches, and other various discomforts.

nox.title: NOx
nox.description: Nitrogen oxide can cause irritation in the eyes, nose, and throat. Symptoms may involve cough, shortness of breath, nausea, etc.

pm.title: PM
pm.description: Particulate matter (PM) pollution from RMC plants can cause respiratory disorders, heart disease, and other health problems.

co.title: CO
co.description: Headaches, nausea, dizziness, and even death can happen when exposed to CO pollution from RMC plants at high concentrations.

rmcGuidelines.title: MPCB Guidelines
rmcGuidelines.subtitle: RMC Plants
rmcGuidelines.description: Maharashtra Pollution Control Board, in consultation with the State Government, has issued guidelines for the siting criteria of Ready Mix Concrete Plants (RMC) in the state of Maharashtra, as well as environmental norms to be enforced on RMCs to implement additional control measures to reduce pollution and protect public health in surrounding areas.

selfAssessment.title: Maharashtra Pollution Control Self Assessment
selfAssessment.description: As per the MPCB, the authority shall comply with the provisions under the Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981, and the following mentioned guidelines.

rmcGuidelines.guidelinesTitle: Guidelines for RMC Plants in Maharashtra, India

guidelines.guideline1: The unit is required to monitor the ambient air quality at the plot boundary
guidelines.guideline2: The ambient air quality standards must be met for a 24-hour average
guidelines.guideline3: The maximum allowable concentration of Particulate Matter (PM10) is 100 μg/m³.
guidelines.guideline4: The maximum allowable concentration of Particulate Matter (PM2.5) is 60 μg/m³.
guidelines.guideline5: Commercial plants are required to install CAAQMS within their premises.
guidelines.guideline6: Captive plants must conduct ambient air quality monitoring twice a week for 24 hours.
guidelines.guideline7: Ready mix concrete industries must comply with the provisions under the Noise Pollution (Regulation and Control) Rule 2000 to control noise pollution.

solutions.title: How do we provide the solutions?

ambient.description: Prana Air Ambient Air Quality Monitors help RMC companies monitor air quality and ensure worker safety. Accurate readings of different air quality parameters, including temperature, allow for proactive measures to mitigate air pollution and improve overall air quality on the plant.

api.description: Prana Air offers seamless integration of air quality monitor data through an API, enabling easy access and integration on any website, in accordance with government guidelines.

cctv.description: By providing remote access to live video footage and real-time air quality data, RMC teams can enhance decision- making processes, ensure compliance with standards, and prioritize the safety of their work environment.

features.feature1: Live video feed of the site

rmcMonitoring.title: Air Quality
rmcMonitoring.description: Our cutting-edge monitoring systems are specifically designed to precisely measure various pollutants including PM, SOx, NOx, CO, and more at RMC plants. With customizable Printed Circuit Boards (PCBs), our monitors are adaptable to real-time applications and can be tailored to meet the specific air quality needs of RMC plant environments.

monitor.title: Ambient Air Monitor (CAAQMS)
monitor.description: Prana Air monitors detect pollutants and function as a CAAQMS for RMC plants, enabling informed decisions, emission control strategies, and improved air quality for worker and community health.

display.title: LED Display & Android TV Dashboard
display.description: Real-time air quality data on displays at construction sites enables informed decisions and proactive health risk mitigation for workers and communities.

storage.title: Cloud Storage & Data Dashboards
storage.description: Cloud storage is crucial for RMC Plants, offering secure remote access to monitored data through mobile apps, Android TV, & web dashboards, anytime, anywhere.

rmcFreemium.title: Data Freemium
rmcFreemium.description: Show the data on LED/LCD TV display or analyze it on a web dashboard or mobile & tablet apps with AQI data cloud storage service. No more hassle of data accessibility.

rmcFaq.description: About Air Quality Monitoring Solutions for RMC Plants Have questions? Were here to help.

questions.q1: 1. Why is air quality monitoring important at RMC sites?
questions.q2: 2. What pollutants are typically monitored at RMC sites?
questions.q3: 3. What are the typical monitoring methods used at RMC sites?
questions.q4: 4. Who is responsible for conducting air quality monitoring at RMC sites?
questions.q5: 5. What are the consequences of non-compliance with air quality standards at RMC sites?
questions.q6: 6. What kind of equipment is used for air quality monitoring at RMC sites?
questions.q7: 7. How often should air quality monitoring be conducted at RMC sites?

answers.a1: Air quality monitoring is crucial at RMC sites to ensure that the emissions from the plants do not cause harmful impacts on public health and the environment.
answers.a2: Common pollutants monitored at RMC sites include particulate matter (PM), NOx, CO, and SOx.
answers.a3: Monitoring methods can vary, but commonly used techniques include continuous ambient air quality monitoring stations (CAAQMS), and real-time monitoring instruments.
answers.a4: Typically, the RMC plant operators are responsible for conducting air quality monitoring at their sites. However, regulatory agencies may also conduct periodic inspections and monitoring to ensure compliance with environmental regulations.
answers.a5: Non-compliance with air quality standards at RMC sites can lead to regulatory action such as fines, shutdowns, or legal action. Additionally, non-compliance can also lead to negative impacts on public health and the environment.
answers.a6: Continuous Ambient Air Quality Monitoring Stations (CAAQMS) are commonly used for air quality monitoring at RMC sites. These systems are capable of measuring various pollutants in real-time and can be customized based on specific monitoring requirements.
answers.a7: Air quality monitoring at RMC sites should be conducted continuously to ensure that the levels of pollutants are within acceptable limits. The frequency of monitoring may vary depending on local regulations and monitoring requirements.
